review_title: Great people, Interesting work, Bad quality of life
pros:
This review is for the law department at HQ in Bethesda, MD. 

*Smart, talented people in the law department and on the business side
*Interesting work. You will learn a lot and never be bored.
*Genuinely nice people in the law department
*Law department is valued by the Company. Will be a respected business partner.
*Opportunities to move over to the business side
cons:
* Horrible work/life balance. You will hear over and over the Company's mantra of "take good care of your associates and they will take good care of the guests and the guests will keep coming back." But it is just a slogan. The Company's actions do not back up its words.
*Not only will you work as hard or harder than you ever worked in a law firm, but the pay will be low. Even before the recent run up in law firm associate salaries, Marriott has for years paid below market. 
*Although the Company values the law department, that value does not extend to compensation or providing appropriate staffing to alleviate a crushing work load.
*Extremely limited opportunities to be promoted.

Join Marriott if you want to work with great, smart people and build your skills. Avoid it if you want to have work life/balance, be paid at market rates, or have a career track.

review_title: Some locations are great, others are career killers.
job_title: Director of Loss Prevention in Denver, CO
pros: The culture of a true location that isn't managed by a team of executives that only care about the bottom line is amazing!
cons:
When you have no support or are looked at as the bottom tier of the industry, you cannot maintain proper staffing levels which leaves management in the Loss Prevention field scrambling for help. When you are a bigger property such as a resort, this is much easier. Once you manager a staff of less than 5 people, It is a career killer as the expectation remains the same for a staff of 15. Which then means, as manager/director, your quality of life is reduced and you are subjected to insane work hours, impossible deadlines, and in the security field, safety and security is only a top priority once something happens that makes the hotel look bad. 

Corporate Integrity Investigations also sides with property HR directors to protect them at all costs in the event they are reported. 

In all, you are on your own.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Antonio, TX
pros: Working at Marriott gives you an entry level opportunity where you are able to grow quickly. They give you the training needed to succeed. Management was great as they really learn more about who you are and that you are not just a number. They are a culturally diverse group. Pre-pandemic, managers arranged for fun activities outside of work which helped learn more about your teammates and relieve stress due to high volume of calls. There was plenty of volunteer opportunities as well. Marriott is known to take care of their people and they really did.
cons: Due to the closure of our center and the pandemic, many promotion opportunities were limited and no raises were given. They gave us a 3 day Take Care PTO that had to be approved by your managers. Working through the pandemic and knowing family and friends who died, the need to have a mental health recovery day was needed. Schedules were changed due to business needs which made it very difficult to switch to and they no longer were willing to work with you.

review_title: A decent place to start, but needs improvement.
pros:
— The people you work alongside are pretty great. There is a strong sense of solidarity among colleagues given how tough the work is.

— There are decent enough opportunities for growth and internal mobility. Most of the people who are in non-customer facing, admin and managerial roles started on the floor in customer facing roles.

— If you can get comfortable in customer-facing roles here, all other jobs will feel much less stressful by comparison. Ultimately, this is a decent place to start your career.

— The employee discount can be great if you are able to find enough time to travel.
cons:
—Scheduling often results in having "split weekends" i.e 2 days off that are not back-to-back.

— The volume of calls is overwhelming, especially considering there is no delay between calls. Ending one usually means a fresh one without even a second to take a breath. Even in internal help desk roles, considered quieter than customer facing ones, you will often receive ~70 calls a day.

— The systems are terrible. It's rare to find a tool or piece of software that is reliable or up to standard considering the volume of work. To be honest, it is embarrassing for a company of this scale. Given the widespread system issues, it can be incredibly disheartening work, especially in technical support roles where you send detailed bug reports that rarely get thoroughly addressed. Granted, these technical issues are far above the responsibility of each contact centre, but it has a huge impact on the morale of employees who use these systems every day. They're not a tech company - but you would expect better from the world's biggest hotel chain.

— Their sick pay policy/process is shameful. It softened a little throughout the pandemic, but it's still not good enough.

— It is incredibly difficult to book PTO.

— There is very little transparency on decision-making from management, and often very little communication prior to major changes in policy/workflows/etc.

— Salary is average and benefits are poor - especially for employees who work remotely (no stipends toward internet bills, home office set up, etc).

review_title: Loyalty  CEC Agent, consistently: Tier 4 earner, #1 in guest commendation < performance standards exceeded
job_title: Customer Loyalty Representative in Fall River, MA
pros:
The money is there if you're looking to make it. They prefer to hire from within, in all cases. Looking for long term employees, if you're not happy with the role you're in they will show you other opportunities that may be a better fit.
Regularly offers advancement.
Unlimited over time. 
Monthly bonus (easily attainable).
Can work from almost anywhere once you're in.
They will help you relocate. Not every position is available everywhere, but if you want to move somewhere new, they will help to get you there and employed with Marriott.
Tons of opportunity to never have to call out, you can use the Trading Board to switch shifts with anyone anywhere (CEC only).
You also have a running bank of absence's, tardy's, leave early's combined with emergency hours (can be put toward and used for any of the aforementioned three) so that you hopefully never run into an issue with attendance.
cons:
At the end of the day, customer service is part of every position (dealing with the public is not always fun).
Their starting wages are the same across the U.S., meaning whether you live in a less expensive area or very expensive area the starting wage is the same (hourly employees).
You make what you make $$ the only way to increase income is to advance to new roles.
You do receive a monthly bonus (great!), if you don't earn your bonus you're up for "coaching" (works more like a quota that you must meet).
There are tools put in place to avoid attendance issues (call outs, being late) but if you run out of or over your allotted attendance occurrences, there is basically zero tolerance (literally it would have to be proven that you have not gone over or unbelievably extenuating circumstances), you will be fired.

review_title: After the Marriott family left, the company was not the same.
job_title: Customer Service Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros:
Before the Marriott family withdrew from the company, Marriott supported the employees and created an atmosphere where an employee was part of the family and felt as if their efforts contributed to Marriott's success. 

The travel benefits are very nice for the employees and their families.
cons:
Afterwards, the Member Services Division became metrics driven versus customer service driven. The newly applied metrics required a rep to attempt to resolve an issue within approximately five minutes. If the call could not be resolved within the time constraints, the rep was required to expedite the complaints, no matter the seriousness of the complaint, to any number of various specialty groups. Otherwise the rep's statistics would be downgraded. In other words, the rep had no choice but to not service the complaint appropriately. The members would call back saying that no one resolved their issue. 

In addition, the pandemic created a phenomenon of people from every walk of life calling in to angrily vent with customer services representatives. The calls became simply outrageous. No amount of money makes this type of position worthwhile. This environment can only lead to dissatisfied members and loss of business.

review_title: Grew too big for its own good
pros:
- Talent and resource availalblity
- Strong global presence and brand recognition 
- Training quality and availability
- Fun challenges and competitions around sales goals 
- Work with reputable companies and great clients
- Remote office with travel as needed to manage customers
- Salary positions with bonus production dependent
cons:
- Company long outgrew the management systems still used 
- Employee focused culture the company was built on is gone and replaced by focus on money and more growth 
- Unrealistic work load and constant feeling of being overwhemed 
- 50 hr standard work week, but actual hours worked far exceeds it without additional compensation
- No trustworthy goal setting process in place for the outside sales teams and costs them in bonus payouts and progressive discipline 
- Lack of trust with immediate supervisor new leadership 
 continues to change that has cost many employees their earned bonuses
- Lots of gossip and high school immature behavior with supervisors engaging in the behaviors themselves 
- More than half of outside sales team members have experienced unfair treatment by their manager and didn't have anyone to turn to
- Human resources was overextended and not available
- Lack of trust between sales orgs and on property management for each hotel, so significant amount of time is wasted on keeping up appearances
- Culture focuses more on beautification and perception than actual performance for carer growth

job_title: Senior Sales and Marketing Assistant in Tucson, AZ
pros:
Career growth
Benefits are great but very expensive
Discounts
Tuition reimbursement
cons:
1)Marriott’s core value is treat your associates good first and they in turn will treat the guest good. I can say that is not how the hotel was managed where I work. 

2) Treat everyone including the worker bees with dignity and respect. Hourly associates are treated like they are disposable. 

3) Upper management yearly salary in addition to their bonuses and incentive programs needs to be reevaluated. Full time hourly associates do not get the additional annual bonuses and incentives on top of their hourly wage. Most associates don’t even get a cost of living wage increase. Unless you go directly into upper management an hourly associate you will make more money working at In/Out fast food restaurant and will most likely be unable to afford the great benefits the company offers.

The hotel discounts are great and very helpful.
cons: To get confirmations and some things done from the corporate office is very slow. Oldschool lacking in technology however they do try.

job_title: Group Housing Coordinator in San Diego, CA
pros: Hotel discounts, low cost lunch.
cons: When you for work Marriott, there is no wiggle room for a pay raise. Marriott budgets out their pays to lower level employees using a set formula. Only the directors and GM’s get paid the really good money. At the specific hotel I worked for, leadership was very focused on how they can save money, not how to treat employees better, despite founding core values. Definitely was a present power imbalances as well.

review_title: Pandemic Pushed A  Great Company over the Edge
pros: Great people work here. Worked with people that had been with the company for 40 years or more in some cases. You sacrifice a lot in hospitality whether you are in one of the hotels directly taking care of guests or whether you were in an office or corporate role trying to make your customers happier. But it always felt worth it and you always felt valued.
cons:
Pandemic showed they only cared about their stock price. 
Benefits continue to get less and less valuable.
Perks are shrinking as more hotels are franchised and the higher ups only care about keeping franchisees happy and wall street happy. 
Pay has never been great but as it gets harder to use your associate rate (and you get treated like a nuisance when you check in with it) the below market pay starts to stand out.
